body.p: This guide covers the basics of using the Application Lifecycle Service (ALS).
To follow along, you will need:

ul.li: a copy of the Helion CLI client

section.title: Management Console
section.p: The web interface for Application Lifecycle Service is called the Management Console. You can use it to:

ul.li: see your current usage and quota
monitor and manage applications you have deployed
see which runtimes, frameworks, and services are available

section.p: To use it, open the API Endpoint URL (e.g. https://api.10.0.0.1.xip.io) in your favorite browser. Log in with the username and password that have been set up for you on the system.

The interface should be mostly self-explanatory. It exposes most of the functionality you have access to as an end user, but to deploy your own applications from source code on your local machine you will need to install and use the Helion Application Lifestyle Service client.

section.title: Application Lifecycle Service Client
section.p: The Helion client pushes applications and provides access to the system from the command line.

ol.li: Download the client for your platform.
Unzip the archive in a convenient directory.

Add the executable to your system/shell \$PATH by:
moving it to a directory in your \$PATH,
creating a symlink from a directory in your \$PATH, or
creating a shell alias for the executable.
Confirm that the client is installed correctly by executing cfmgmt help.

section.p: Refer to the Application Lifecycle Service Client Command Reference for a complete list of commands and options.

section.title: Target and Log In
section.p: To connect the helion client to the PaaS, use the target command to specify the API Endpoint URL. This is normally the hostname prepended with "api." for example:
section.codeblock: helion target api.example.hphelion.com Target: https://api.example.hphelion.com Organization: <none> Space: <none> Successfully targeted to [https://api.example.hphelion.com]
section.p: Once you have successfully targeted Application Lifecycle Service, you must authenticate using helion login with the credentials that have been created for you:
section.codeblock: helion login user@example.com Attempting login to [https://api.example.hphelion.com] Password: ******** Successfully logged into [https://api.example.hphelion.com]

section.title: Setting Organization and Space
section.p: If you are logging in for the first time, your user account will not automatically choose an Organization and Space for deployment. You will need to set these manually.
To set the Organization you belong to:
section.codeblock: helion switch-org *org-name* Switching to organization *org-name* ... OK Unsetting current space ... OK Target: https://api.stacka.to Organization: *org-name* Space: <none>
section.p: To set the Space you want to deploy applications to:
section.codeblock: helion switch-space dev Switching to organization *org-name* ... OK Switching to space dev ... OK Target: https://api.stacka.to Organization: test-org Space: dev
section.note: If your account is not a member of a Space, you will need an Organization Manager to add you as a Developer. If you are an Organization Manager or Admin, you can create new Spaces in the Management Console or with the helion create-space command.

section.title: Sample Applications
section.p: Small sample applications in various programming languages are available. These applications demonstrate the basics of ALS deployment (hello world), connect to a database, and exercise the Messaging Broker Service.
Additional more advanced sample applications are available from Application Lifecycle Service-Apps on Github, each with a README.md file showing how to deploy it on Application Lifecycle Service.
Many of these have a manifest.yml configuration file, so you can skip the interactive prompts by using the -n option.
